# Linear Regression Model
## Relevant Space and Relevant Components

---
class: top, left

# Linear Regression Model
.pull-left[

- Regression coefficients $\beta$ controls the relationship between the predictor $(\mathbf{x})$ and response $(\mathbf{y})$
- Not all variation in the $\mathbf{y}$ is explained by $\mathbf{x}$
- The error captures the rest that is left by the model
- Different prediction and estimation methods uses different model to figure out these $\beta$ close to the truth in order to achieve better prediction and stable estimation


].pull-right.with-figure[

```{r, out.extra='style="padding-bottom: 12px;"'}
knitr::include_graphics("_images/animated/relevant-space.svg")
```

.caption[ Linear Regression between `\\(\mathbf{x}\\)` and `\\(\mathbf{y}\\)` ]

$$\mathbf{y} = \mu_y + \beta^t(\mathbf{x} - \mu_x) + \varepsilon, \; \; \varepsilon \sim \mathsf{N}(0, \sigma^2)$$

The regression coefficient is the covariance between $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$ scaled by the variance of $\mathbf{x}$, i.e.
$$\beta=\Sigma_{xx}^{-1}\sigma_{xy}$$

]

---
class: top, left
# Relevant Space and Relevant Components

.pull-left[

- Only a subspace (relevant space) of predictor space are relevant for explaining variation in $\mathbf{y}$ 
- A subset of latent components that spans this space are the _relevant components_
- Methods like principal component regression (PCR) and partial least squares (PLS) are based on this concept
- Leveraging the idea, `r Citet(refs, 'saebo2015simrel')` developed a simulation tool called `simrel`
- In the second paper, using the tool, we performed a simulation comparison on various methods including BayesPLS, PLS and Envelopes

].pull-right.with-figure[

```{r, child="_images/animated/relevant-space.svg"}
```

.caption[ Linear Regression between `\\(\mathbf{x}\\)` and `\\(\mathbf{y}\\)` with relevant spaces within them. ]

]
